key_insight: A unified lattice-coding view reveals why some lookup-free non-parametric quantizers need auxiliary losses, and the paper introduces Spherical Leech Quantization (SLQ) — a lattice-informed, sphere-projected quantization scheme tailored for scalable visual tokenization and generation.
problem_solved: Addresses instability and design ambiguity in non-parametric (lookup-free) vector quantization for visual tokenizers: how to build large, efficient codebooks with consistent training behavior and principled geometry.
method: Formulate existing non-parametric quantization methods through lattice coding to expose geometric causes (e.g., Voronoi structure) of training pathologies.
Analyze why auxiliary loss terms become necessary for certain lookup-free variants (like BSQ) based on lattice geometry and neighbor relationships.

Propose Spherical Leech Quantization (SLQ): map embeddings onto a sphere and leverage Leech-lattice-inspired code arrangements to create a dense, structured, lookup-free codebook suitable for tokenization and generation.
impact: Provides a principled, geometry-aware route to build large, parameter-efficient visual codebooks that improve stability and scalability of tokenizers and generative pipelines — useful for practitioners seeking compact models and better-designed quantizers.
visual_elements: Comparative diagram: lattice vs spherical codebook layouts (Voronoi cells) to show geometric differences and where auxiliary losses arise

paper_title: Spherical Leech Quantization for Visual Tokenization and Generation
paper_authors: Yue Zhao, Hanwen Jiang, Zhenlin Xu, Chutong Yang, Ehsan Adeli
